head.title: Judge Dismisses 75 On Bomb Jury Panel

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New York

hedline.hl1: Judge Dismisses 75 On Bomb Jury Panel

block.p: Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of the man accused of masterminding the World Trade Center bombing, and the difficulty of finding a panel for the sensitive case became clear when the first 75 prospective jurors were dismissed.
Judge Kevin T. Duffy, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, let the jurors go for fear they would be influenced by the heavy security.

Jury selection began yesterday in the trial of the man accused of masterminding the World Trade Center bombing, and the difficulty of finding a panel for the sensitive case became clear when the first 75 prospective jurors were dismissed.
Judge Kevin T. Duffy, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, let the jurors go for fear they would be influenced by the heavy security.

The main defendant, Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, 29, is accused of masterminding the World Trade Center bombing on Feb. 26, 1993, which killed six people. But he is not being tried in that case yet. The current trial is on charges that he put a bomb aboard Philippine Airlines Flight 434 on Dec. 11, 1994, causing an explosion that killed a man.

Prosecutors said Mr. Yousef, Abdul Hakim Murad and Wali Khan Amin Shah then plotted to bomb 11 United States airliners in one day over the Far East, in an effort to pressure the United States into playing a lesser role in the Middle East.
